rule: Impact Hierarchy: Fit/Ease 30%, Construction 25%, Fabric behavior 20%, Surface finish 15%, Color 10%. Color is OVERWEIGHTED 5x in popular advice.
implication: A well-fitting matte ponte dress in medium blue looks dramatically better than a poorly fitting black satin dress, despite the blue adding 2% perceived width and the black removing 5%.

rule: All effects scored on -1.0 to +1.0 scale. -1.0 = Maximum volume reduction (compression + dark + matte + structure bridging). 0.00 = Cotton poplin baseline. +1.0 = Maximum volume amplification (cling + shiny + light + projected).
stacking_formula: total = sign x (1 - (1-|a|)(1-|b|)(1-|c|)...). Same-direction effects stack with DIMINISHING RETURNS, not linearly. Prevents unrealistic compounding and naturally caps near +/-1.0.

rule: Woven vs Knit Elastane Multiplier: Same elastane percentage = completely different stretch behavior. Getting this wrong produces 200-400% errors in stretch prediction.
priority: #1 priority correction from the failure catalog

rule: Effective GSM (Fiber-Adjusted): Same GSM, different fiber = different perceived weight/stiffness.
The Ponte Advantage: Rayon/nylon/elastane double knit (~300gsm, drape 5) consistently scores as the optimal fabric for bodies with curves.
reasons: Drape 5 = sweet spot between cling (drape 7+) and projection (drape 3-)
Double knit = smooth surface without body-documenting conformity
Recovery rate ~92% = maintains shape across wear cycles
Thickness = built-in smoothing layer (like permanent lining)
ponte_limitation: Ponte traps heat. In hot/humid climates (above ~80F/27C), ponte becomes uncomfortable. Alternative: polyester crepe (drape 5-6, ~180gsm).

rule: Apple belly effective front ease: max(0, total_ease - belly_projection x 0.8). Apple belly ALWAYS clings in fluid garments regardless of total ease.
example: At 4" total ease with 4" belly projection: effective front ease = 0.8". At 3" total ease with 4" projection: effective front ease = 0".

rule: Hourglass Sizing Paradox: Size for bust/hip -> waist has 8-14" EXCESS ease -> boxy silhouette. Size for waist -> bust/hip cling at 45-65% demand -> strain everywhere. No single size fits in non-stretch garments.
Plus Size Compound Cling Effect: Higher circumferences + steeper curvature rates = lower thresholds at ALL zones. Upper arm becomes significant cling zone (14-20" circ).

Hourglass Waist - Structure is WORSE than Cling: Structure at hourglass waist fills the concavity, ERASING the waist definition. Proportion_erosion +0.15-0.25. Moderate cling preserves waist definition better than structure.

Petite in Heavy Fluid Long Garments REVERSAL: 'Avoid heavy fabrics if petite' REVERSES for heavy-but-fluid (drape 7+, gsm 200+) in full-length garments. Heavy fluid in maxi creates unbroken vertical fall lines that ELONGATE.

When surface sheen > 0.15 on a dark garment at a curved zone, the highlight contrast cancels the dark-color benefit. At sheen 0.50: dark benefit fully cancelled (net zero). At sheen 0.75+: dark is actively WORSE than medium-tone matte.

Petite Color Paradox: Dark reduces BOTH width AND height. OPTIMAL: Monochrome in medium tones (lightness 30-60%), creating longest unbroken vertical line. Elongation benefit of monochrome (-0.05 to -0.10 proportion score) is MORE valuable than +/-0.15 width change from dark vs light.
Pear Zone Color Strategy: Light top adds +0.10-0.20 width at narrow shoulders (beneficial). Dark bottom removes -0.15-0.30 at wide hips (beneficial). Combined effect: 2x more effective than all-dark.

12 Independent Body Dimensions: Standard body types capture only 1 of 12 independent dimensions. Two 'pear' bodies with identical bust-waist-hip ratios but different heights, belly projections, and tissue firmness will have completely different experiences.
dimensions: 1. Height: Pattern overwhelm, hemline zones, proportional dominance of curves
2. Bust circumference: Bust cling demand, button gap risk
3. Waist circumference: Sizing anchor for most garments
4. Hip circumference: Hip cling demand, A-line behavior
5. Shoulder width: Silhouette frame, sleeve fit
6. Bust-waist differential: Bust curvature rate, dart need
7. Hip-waist differential: Hip curvature rate, sizing paradox
8. Torso length: Curvature rate modulator (short torso = steeper rates at same differentials)
9. Bust projection (anterior): Sheen amplification, photo gap, cling
10. Belly projection: #1 photo gap contributor, cling threshold, bridging calculation, wrap gap risk
11. Hip projection (lateral): Stripe reversal, A-line behavior
12. Tissue firmness: Compression artifacts, cling visual severity

rule: Scoring Engine Pipeline: Input -> Phase 1 (Fabric Resolution) -> Phase 2 (Body Metric Derivation) -> Phase 3 (Zone Selection) -> Phase 4 (Per-Zone Scoring across 10 principles with diminishing returns) -> Phase 5 (Context Modifiers: sitting, climate) -> Phase 6 (Composite + Recommendation).
